portfolio.title: Crystal Set Radio
portfolio.description: Crystal set radio targeting the radio frequency 680 kHz with an inductor that allows for manual tuning.

portfolio.title: Rock Paper Scissors
portfolio.description: Two-player rock-paper-scissor game created on a breadboard and then transferred to an FPGA.

portfolio.title: Simple CPU
portfolio.description: CPU composed of a 9-bit processor, memory module, and counter. Implemented on a DE10-Lite FPGA.

portfolio.title: D&E: Sustainable Food Systems
portfolio.description: Potential solutions to make food systems more sustainable at the University of Pittsburgh based on student interviews.

radio.title: Inductor
radio.description: I started by creating an inductor out of wire wrapped around a section of PVC pipe. I could manually tune this inductor by adding or removing loops of wire.

radio.title: Capacitor
radio.description: After calculating the inductance, I created a capacitor out of aluminum foil on either side of a sheet of paper with a capacitance that would satisfy the equation f = 1/[2π(LC)^1/2].

radio.title: Complete Circuit
radio.description: Finally, I assembled the full circuit which included the inductor and capcitor I had built, as well as a 3 volt battery, antenae, germanium diode, and piezoelectric earphone.

digital-circuits-1.title: Rock Paper Scissors
digital-circuits-1.description: Allows for two users to play rock-paper-scissors using two buttons. LEDS indicate which player wins, or if either player has not made any inputs.

digital-circuits-1.title: 2-Bit Multiplier
digital-circuits-1.description: User can input two values equaling 1, 2, or 3 using a DIP Input component. LEDs display result of multiplication in binary.

digital-circuits-2.title: XOR Gate
digital-circuits-2.description: Circuit design for an XOR Gate without using and XOR logic chip. LED turns on when either buttons is pushed, but not when both are pushed.

digital-circuits-2.title: CMOS NAND Gate
digital-circuits-2.description: Using NMOS and PMOS transistors, created a circuit where the LED is on by default, but turns off if either of the buttons are pushed.

rps.title: Kmaps & Equations
rps.description: Circuit design for an XOR Gate without using and XOR logic chip. LED turns on when either buttons is pushed, but not when both are pushed.

rps.title: Circuit Diagram
rps.description: Using NMOS and PMOS transistors, created a circuit where the LED is on by default, but turns off if either of the buttons are pushed.

processor.title: Instructions
processor.description: Using NMOS and PMOS transistors, created a circuit where the LED is on by default, but turns off if either of the buttons are pushed.

processor.title: Diagram
processor.description: Circuit design for an XOR Gate without using and XOR logic chip. LED turns on when either buttons is pushed, but not when both are pushed.

prototypes.title: Build Your Own Meal Machine
prototypes.description: The user accesses an interface after being recognized, enters their name and school ID, and selects locally sourced ingredients or premade meals. Limited combinations are available, and nutritional facts are provided before payment. Once paid, the meal is quickly served, offering a healthy, campus-made dining experience.

prototypes.title: Calorie Counter
prototypes.description: ​This is an app that connects to your Pitt ID to automatically log meals and track nutritional information. It will also display the options at University dining halls to allow for manual logging. This information is anonymously shared with the University to help them better predict the dietary needs of the student body so less food goes to waste.

prototypes.title: Healthy Snack Stand
prototypes.description: This mini dining hall offers healthy snacks like fresh fruit and granola bars in a convenient, sustainable way. Located in a high-traffic area, it features an ID scanner that deducts one meal or Dining Dollars/Panther Funds upon entry. Students can quickly grab healthy snacks in a reusable to-go box that must be brought back.
